Hi guys,

Something totally new!

Just following up on some usability feedback from our testing in the winter/spring.

One idea was to animate the 5 promo pictures on the homepage so that they scroll through all of them.  Also included in this idea was replacing the 1-5 blue buttons with thumbnails (obviously they'd need to be slightly larger).  Without us going off and getting the thing redesigned, do you think this is something you could do?  Give it some thought (and a quote) and we can try and figure out how to go forward!

Liz

Liz Goulding
New Media Producer
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games
Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297
Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000
www.london2012.com
www.twitter.com/london2012
Priority set to high (so that it gets out attention).

Liz,

Rather than thumbnails (unless I am missing something we are very tight on space there) how about as we automatically scroll though the images, get the text and the relevant blue box to highlight.

On top of that what about making the boxes more arrow like, so that it highlights a natural flow, although there is a danger that it will be to indicative of a 'steps' and dissuade people from missing a step. Trying to find an example but will give it a go in words first in case you go "Oh I know what you mean" ;-) Basically change the background of each [number] so that it becomes a interlocked arrow with the next box.

Jamie

Hmm. I agree on the space issue. One thought we had was to arrange the thumbnails vertically, rather than horizontally, but that’s a bit more design work. The idea was that the thumbnails actually indicate there are more photos coming rather than blue boxes.

That said, I like the idea of a ‘natural flow’ so long as people don’t take it too literally and thing that they are sequential (they’re not).

I’m thinking that we’re probably safer if we do some mock-ups, as I reckon we’ll need a ‘pause’ button, too, for accessibility reasons.
I certainly think we need some mockups first, will get the paint box out later...

Liz,

Jamie was suggesting let's try something light'n'subtle with the current homepage keeping your aims in sight:
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/index.php

Here's what it does:
- the numbers are changing on hover, there's a little border (inviting for action)
- also, there's a tooltip with the article title on the numbers
- if no one is doing anything (and the cursor is not in the area), it automatically goes around the banners (one step in 10 seconds)

This is ready to go live now.

Wrt the new homepage, Jamie suggested http://www.timeout.com/ with a very nice and usable carousel, but I'm more than happy to have a look around and shop for different solutions so when it comes to designing, we'll have a good idea where to go.
I think it looks like a great first step, at least. Let me get some feedback from the rest of the team before we go live!

I'm wondering if there's final thumbs-up w/ this. Jamie says you're happy with the webcam changes, but waiting for approvals, and you have some accessibility concerns about the header changer. I did some research - here are the results:

- The carousel is updating very slowly, once in every 30 seconds - The likelihood of this causing any accessibility issues is very low.
- We could introduce a pause button - which make the ui more confusing as the page is almost static. I'd strongly advise against this.
- We could add some clever logic to figure if the user is a screen reader user or not - this would involve some extra work, and I doubt it's strictly necessary to meet accessibility guidelines, but if you want to be 110% sure, I'm more than happy to add it.

Either way, would be great if we could get this (and the webcam story as well) sorted by the end of the day :)

Sorry Janos – not quite good to go. But I’m aware of the pressure of the ‘technology freeze’ if that’s why you are eager to get it sorted?

For the webcams – how difficult would it be for us to choose which webcam went up every day – or at least manually override it if we happened to randomly get one that was down that day (apparently it happens)? If we can get reassurance on that, I think we’d be ok.

Fir the carousel – can we mimic the functionality here: http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/volunteer/index.php then I think we’d be ok Accessibility-wise.
Then pause button it is. Should take a bit of extra time to make it fit next to the 1-5 buttons, but shouldn't be much more than a day altogether. Trying to clean this up asap.
Cool. And is the highlighted button now pink (in line with the photos/volunteer landing page)
Looking now.

http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/index.php
play-pause monster is in preview now - ready to be published.
Looks fantastic! How long is the delay between pictures? My instinct is to speed it up a smidge...

10 seconds at the moment.
I'd rather not push it live at 6 - first thing tomorrow.
Can we make it 7 seconds transition before we push live? But then yes, go ahead.
it's live!
It’s not really fitting properly, Janos! The pause button has gone down a line. (take a look at it in firefox ... my IE on my main computer hasn’t gotten the published version yet).
And the highlighted number isn’t pink!!
AND the pause button only slows it down – it doesn’t stop it!
Ha, that was weird - it seems syncing happened very-very slowly this time, but now all my browsers show the most recent version.
Ah! That looks better.
But. The pause button still doesn’t actually pause?
Righto – i think it’s pausing, but where you are in the 1-5 rectangles isn’t staying highlighted!
Should stay pink now.
Thank you!
Marking as solved.

comments.value: This should prevent Translations.com translating a page twice before they have had a chance to log the previous translation.

afaik, pages don't get a "sent" state - but the translation log items do - or at least they did, in the old client. So the simple solution would be for the translation feed to silently discard unactioned requests. I'm assuming LOCOG understand the consequences of this change: some updates will not be translated.
Rumour says you're rejigging translation on the new client. In which case, you might want to bear this (billable) requirement in mind.

To flesh out Michael's point re. updates:
Lets say a page is "Sent for translation" by an editor.
The feed then runs, and sends this page to Translation.com.
The editor then realizes that there's a glaring (unpublishable) typo in the page.
If he resends it for translation are we to:
 (a) Silently ignore this request.
 (b) Show a message saying "Sorry, already sent. please wait until the page arrives back from Translation.com, and then remember to come back and resend this page for translation.".
 (c) Display a confirmation dialog, asking the user whether they want to FORCIBLY resend this page for translation.
 (d) Some other solution.
I believe we need some feedback on what behaviour you want here.

Is there another possible solution, in which the page is sent to
Translations.com but with a flag to the effect "You have recently
received this page but a change has been made. Please use this version
of the document for translation"? That would mean that they are aware of
a more recent version and can discard the earlier version of the doc?

 

________________________________

Have upped the priority, and also added an estimate of 1 day.
This is for Morag's (I think very sensible) idea.
Another option is to generate an message saying: "Sorry this page has already been sent for translation". This would be 0 days.
"Sorry, this page has already been sent, click HERE to forcibly re-send it" would be 1.5 days (kieran + janos).
This ticket was closed and merged into ticket #1164 "Translation - AL integratiom".

subject: Do not allow pages in a "Sent" state to be re-sent for translation.
description: This should prevent Translations.com translating a page twice before they have had a chance to log the previous translation.

Hello Abilitynet have found some issues with the Get ready to apply page - are you able to review please? http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/volunteer/get-ready-to-apply.php Thanks! ----- Original Message ----- From: Jon Gooday [mailto:jon.gooday@abilitynet.org.uk] Sent: Thursday, September 16, 2010 06:55 PM To: Morag Reavley Cc: Meera Tank Subject: RE: Extra page to check Hi Morag We have found a few issues 1. Flash video The Flash video is inaccessible to screen readers because of the way it has been embedded in the page The wmode is set to opaque rather than 'Window' so the video and link to the transcript is invisible For background: the wmode parameter is used to control how a Flash movie interacts with other web page elements. There are three modes: * Window (the default if the parameter isn't included): used to show a Flash movie in its own rectangular window on a web page. The background colour will be whatever is set in Flash when you export the movie. The only mode that is accessible to screen readers * Opaque: with this setting you can use JavaScript to move the movie around the page, or resize it. * Transparent: other content on the page will show through all the transparent parts of the Flash movie - basically, the colour background set when the movie is exported gets ignored. Transparent / opaque wmode is the equivalent of CSS display:none, and screen readers don't even announce there's a Flash movie present. if wmode is set to anything other than 'window' the Flash movie will be completely inaccessible to screen readers, undoing any good work you may have done with the accessibility properties. . 2. Error icon - see error_icon.png There is a mismatch between the '!' icon under Handy hints and what you get on the following form ( an 'i' within a red triangle). Also this is unclear to a screen reader user so it would be better to replace the (!) with an actual error icon - I know this would mess with the all blue design but it would be clearer. 3. Step 1 to Step 3 Step1: Watch the video.. is visually clear but what is read out by a screen reader is just 'Watch the video'. 'Step 2: Registration' is just read out as 'Registration' so you need to add in Step1: , Step 2: etc to the code as below so it makes more sense:
Step 1: Watch the video
Step 2: Registration
Click 'Apply now' to register. You'll need your own email address and must make sure no one else uses it for their own registration. You'll also need to create a password.
4. Empty link on 'Visiting in 2012' sub menu This appears to a template issue - the link Visit London 2012 sub navigation is missing a text description - see empty_link.png which shows you a screen reader links list with the relevant link highlighted. To fix this change the code : From Visiting in 2012< to a href="visiting/">Visiting in 2012Visiting in 2012 sub navigation< Thanks, Jon
those are all done

We would like to restructure this page as follows:

Feature Eddie Izzard video in blog-size player at top of page (between blue lines) - this needs to be editable, so that if we have to swap in a modified version we can do. Steps 1, 2 and 3 to go either underneath or to the right of the video player. 

Two columns with icons and bullet points - we want to restructure this so that the left hand column has a header 'Checklist', with the following bullet points:
-Make sure you’re eligible
-You’ll need your own email address and must make sure no one else uses it to submit another application. 
-You’ll need to provide details of one of the following documents:
Applicants from the UK – a passport or photocard driving licence. If you have neither of these, follow the instructions in Step 1 of the application form.
Applicants from the European Economic Area (EEA) and Switzerland – a passport or identity card.
Applicants from countries outside of the EEA/Switzerland – a passport. 
-You’ll need to provide expiry dates of any first aid certificates.
 
NB the are currently no icons for 'make sure you're eligible' and 'Expiry dates of any first aid certificates' - these will be provided

Right hand column to be given a header 'Handy hints', with the following content:
- All fields marked with an asterisk (*) are mandatory.
- If you see a (!) icon, there is an error on the page. Make sure you answer the question or enter details as instructed. 
- If you need further explanation about a question,
hover your mouse over the help icon (?).

Icons are already available for these bullet points.

Bottom of page to stay as is.

See doc attached for schematic of how this works.

Many thanks!

Morag
